title: ‘Fake rape claim’ Brit says retraction statement was written in ‘Greek English’
text:
The 19-year-old says police forced her to sign a retraction statement (Picture: AFP/EPA)

A British teenager accused of lying about being gang raped told a court she was forced to sign a retraction statement written in ‘Greek English’ and littered with grammar mistakes.

The 19-year-old, who cannot be identified, broke down in tears as she was cross-examined for over three hours on Wednesday.

She is accused of causing public mischief by allegedly falsely claiming she was raped by up to 12 Israeli tourists in a hotel room in Ayia Napa on July 17.

The woman said she was forced by police to make a retraction statement 10 days later fearing she would be ‘kidnapped or killed’.

Prosecutors say she willingly wrote and signed the document, but her lawyers say she was told what to write by Cypriot police, led by Detective Sergeant Marios Christou.

The teenager alleged that 12 Israelis gang raped her at the hotel where she was staying in the popular Ayia Napa resort (Picture: AFP)

‘Marios wanted me to write that it was made up but it’s not in proper English,’ the woman told Famagusta District Court, in Paralimni.

Advertisement

‘This is not in proper English. This is in Greek English.

‘I’m very well educated. I’m going to university, I got an unconditional offer so there is no way I would write a paragraph like this.’

The teenager added: ‘It doesn’t make grammatical sense.

‘All the way through there isn’t one sentence an English person would write.’

A friend, who she met at the airport and shared a room with, also claimed police added details to her own statement, which she deleted when the officer left the room.

The psychology graduate said: ‘He wrote something in the statement that I didn’t actually say.

‘It was in reference to how much we had been drinking.’

The defendant told the court she arrived in Cyprus, then aged 18, a week before the alleged rape in an ‘attempt to grow up’ before going to university.

‘I’m academically educated, (but) I’m 18 years old I have no life experience. I don’t know how life works,’ she recounted.

Some of the Israeli tourists leave court following an earlier hearing (Picture: AFP)

The Israelis arrested in connection with the allegations all returned home after they were released (Picture: EPA)

She wept as she admitted lying to her mother in a text sent from the police station which said: ‘Trust me, I’m OK.’

‘I think any child will lie to their parents to tell them they are OK because parents don’t stop worrying about their child,’ she added.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘If your child had just been raped by 12 Israelis and wouldn’t get out of bed and had a throat so swollen she couldn’t breathe and was taken to the police station for what she thought was an hour but then went on to be nearly eight hours.’

The teenager said she ‘felt vulnerable’ while she was at the police station because the detective ‘wasn’t going by the law’ and she ‘wasn’t allowed a lawyer’.

‘I immediately assumed corruption and conspiracy so I wouldn’t put it past him, I wouldn’t be surprised if at that moment he would have kidnapped me and killed me,’ she said.

The woman spent four-and-a-half weeks in prison before she was granted bail at the end of August, but cannot leave the island.

She could face up to a year in jail and a 1,700 euro (roughly £1,500) fine if she is convicted.

The 12 young Israeli men arrested in connection with the allegations all returned home after they were released.

The trial continues on Thursday.
